item.title: Magic Rituals
item.description: To cast a spell, you must usually perform a ritual that involves gestures and speech. If you can’t perform the ritual, you can’t cast the spell! For instance, if the ritual for a spell requires you to speak, you cannot cast the spell if you are gagged or under a spell of silence.      The higher your skill with a spell, the easier it is to cast: it takes less time, requires less energy, and has less stringent ritual requirements. See the list below for details. In all cases, “skill” refers to base skill, not effective skill. The only modifier that matters here is the -5 for low mana, if applicable.Skill 9 or less – Ritual: You must have both hands and both feet free for elaborate ritual movements,and you must speak certain words of power in a firm voice. Time: Doubled. Cost: As listed. Skill 10-14 – Ritual: You must speak a few quiet words and make a gesture. Time: As listed. Cost: As listed. Skill 15-19 – Ritual: You must speak a word or two or make a small gesture (a couple of fingers are enough), but not necessarily both. You are allowed to move one yard per second while taking the Concentrate maneuver. Time: As listed. Cost: Reduced by 1. Skill 20-24 – Ritual: None! You simply stare into space as you concentrate. Time: Halved (round fractions up to the next second). Minimum casting time is still one second. Cost: Reduced by 2. Skill 25-29 – Ritual: None. Time: Divided by 4 (round up). Cost: Reduced by 3. Skill 30 or more – As above, but for every five levels of skill beyond skill 25 (that is, at levels 30, 35, 40, etc.), halve casting time again and reduce energy cost by one more point.  Certain spells always require a specific ritual. Such requirements override the rules above. For instance, high skill has no effect on the cost to cast Blocking spells (p. 241) or the time to cast Missile spells (p. 240).

item.title: Magery and Effect
item.description:
Talented mages may exceed the usual limits for spells that allow a finite number of “levels of effect” (dice of damage, bonuses to skill, etc.). The upper limit is the higher of the standard number of levels or the caster’s Magery level.
Example: Major Healing allows you to spend 1, 2, 3, or 4 energy points to heal 2, 4, 6, or 8 HP. It has four levels of effect. Magery 10 would let you revise this limit to 10 levels of effect – you could spend 1-10 energy points to heal 2-20 HP!
The GM is free not to use this rule if he thinks it would be unbalanced. Of course, if he puts a limit on the highest level of Magery available, this is not a problem!
item.guid: 10_System_Rules/11_Core_Gurps/General Abilities Article/Basic Set - Characters/Magic (Chapter 5)/Magery and Effect.md

item.title: Types of Disadvantages
item.description: Mental disadvantages originate from your mind or soul. They stay with you if your mind ends up in a new body. This category includes the vast majority of "magical," "psionic," and "spiritual" traits.Mental disadvantages are marked 3.Physical disadvantages are associated with your body. You can escape them by moving to a new body! If another mind occupies your body, the new owner gains your physical disadvantages.You can acquire a physical disadvantage during play, most likely due to accident or combat. In this case, you immediately suffer the bad effects of the disadvantage. Unlike starting disadvantages, however, physical handicaps acquired in play do not "give back" points with which to buy abilities - they just lower your point value!Example: If you start out blind, you start with an extra 50 points . . . but if an explosion blinds you during the game, you're just blind and that's that. Reduce your point total by 50 points to reflect your new disadvantage. You should not keep the same point total and take 50 points of compensating advantages!Physical disadvantages are marked 1.Social disadvantages are associated with your identity. Should it become important to know whether they go with mind or body, the GM's word is I final. Note that this category includes below-average Status, Wealth, and so I forth from Chapter 1.Social disadvantages are marked 2.The GM is the final judge of which category a disadvantage belongs in. It is possible to interpret certain disadvantages in more than one way!Exotic disadvantages are forbidden to normal humans. Nonhumans may acquire such traits from their racial template (see Chapter 7), but they still need the GM's permission to take additional exotic disadvantages.Exotic disadvantages are marked 4.Supernatural disadvantages are the result of divine intervention, magic, psionics, etc. With the GM's permission, anyone might be cursed in this way - but only if supernatural powers exist in the game world.Supernatural disadvantages are marked 5.Mundane disadvantages are everything else. They are inborn, acquired, or self-imposed handicaps that anyone might have. Mundane disadvantages are not marked in any special way. Assume that a disadvantage with neither 9 nor / is available to anyone.1234567890
item.guid: 10_System_Rules/11_Core_Gurps/General Abilities Article/Basic Set - Characters/Disadvantages/Types of Disadvantages.md

item.title: Self-Control for Mental Disadvantages
item.description: Many mental disadvantages do not affect you constantly - you may attempt to control your urges. An asterisk (*) appears next to the point cost of any disadvantage that offers a chance to resist. For each disadvantage like this, you must choose a selfcontrol number: the number you must roll on 3d to avoid giving in. This modifies point value as follows:You resist quite rarely (roll of 6 or less): 2 x listed cost.You resist fairly often (roll of 9 or less): 1.5 x listed cost.You resist quite often (roll of 12 or less): listed cost.You resist almost all the time (roll of 15 or less): 0.5 x listed cost.Drop all fractions (e.g., -22.5 points becomes -22 points).The "default" self-control number is 12: you must roll 12 or less on 3d to avoid giving in to your problem. This lets you use disadvantage costs as written. Choose a self-control number of 15 if you wish to have a tendency toward a disadvantage instead of a full-blown case. A self-control number of 9 will regularly limit your options. A self-control number of 6 can be crippling (especially with genuine psychiatric problems).Note your self-control number in parentheses after the name of the disadvantage on your character sheet. For instance, if you can resist Berserk on a roll of 9 or less, write this as "Berserk (9)."In circumstances that are likely to trigger your problem, you may opt to roll 3d against your self-control number to see whether your disadvantage actually affects you. If you roll less than or equal to this number, you resist your disadvantage - this time. Otherwise, you suffer the listed effects. This is called a self-control roll.Like all success rolls, self-control rolls arc subject to modifiers. Exceptionally mild or severe stimuli can give bonuses or penalties. Drugs and afflictions can make you more or less likely to give in. Other disadvantages can make you irritable, reducing your odds of resisting. See the disadvantage descriptions for details.Example: Your self-control number is 15, but you are in a highly stressful situation that gives -5 to your self-control roll. You must roll 10 or less to resist your disadvantage. You never have to try a self-control roll - you can always give in willingly, and it is good roleplaying to do so. However, there will be times when you really need to resist your urges, and that is what the roll is for. Be aware that if you attempt self-control rolls too often, the GM may penalize you for bad roleplaying by awarding you fewer earned points.Optionally, the GM may permit you to use one unspent character point to "buy" an automatic success on a selfcontrol roll. Points spent this way are gone for good, but there will be times when staying on the straight and narrow is worth the sacrifice. In this case, the GM should not penalize you for bad roleplaying, because you are penalizing yourself!Note that high Will helps you make Fright Checks and resist supernatural emotion control, but it does not improve self-control rolls - not even for disadvantages with effects identical to these things. Mental disadvantages represent an aspect of your personality that you cannot simply will (or reason) away. This is part of what makes them disadvantages!
item.guid: 10_System_Rules/11_Core_Gurps/General Abilities Article/Basic Set - Characters/Disadvantages/Self-Control for Mental Disadvantages.md

item.title: Firearm Notes
item.description: If a single rapid-fire attack scores multiple hits, a successful Dodge roll lets you avoid one hit, plus additional hits equal to your margin of success. A critical success lets you dodge all hits you took from that attack. Example: A machine gun gets four hits against you. Your Dodge is 10. You roll an 8, succeeding by 2. You dodge three of the hits; only one bullet strikes you.

item.title: Identifying the Good Stuff
item.description:
Not all loot looks like loot. Some has hidden properties that make it more valuable – or trash. Professional dungeon crawlers need special skills to figure out what to keep, sell, and discard. Except as noted, the rolls called for here identify the treasure but not its fair market value.Coin: Assume that any delver who isn’t completely illiterate (as barbarians often are) can count and evaluate coin: a copper farthing is $1; a silver penny, $4; and a gold piece, $80. Copper is $62.50/lb.; silver, $1,000/lb.; and gold, $20,000/lb. To avoid being ripped off, bring scales and weigh it all!Stones: Everybody knows that shiny rocks are valuable. To tell semiprecious stones from gemstones, make a Merchant roll. All trained dungeon fantasy merchants seem to know about gems.
Luxury Items: To know fine incense from cathouse perfume, rare tropical woods from common types, ermine from rat fur, etc., roll against a suitable Connoisseur specialty.
Rare Artifacts: Some things, especially artwork, are valuable because of who made or owned them, or by dint of some other historical quirk. Make a Connoisseur roll to spot a potential item of this kind – and a Forgery roll to discover whether it’s real or a fake! A Heraldry roll might deduce makers or past owners from marks left on the item (GM’s decision).
Superior Weapons and Armor: Roll against an appropriate Armoury specialty to spot better-than-average arms and armor, including such properties as “balanced,” “dwarven,” and “meteoric.”Blessed Items: A Perception roll with bonus equal to Holiness or Power Investiture lets those with either trait spot a blessed (or cursed) item. A cleric can take four hours to pray to his god and get the full details by making a Religious Ritual roll. Critical failure triggers any curse present.
Magic Items: The most reliable way to spot magic items is for a wizard to make his Perception + Magery roll on sight or on touch. Use the Analyze Magic spell to reveal specific enchantments. A delver with a backpack alchemy lab can take an hour and make an Alchemy roll at -2 to learn the item’s general abilities (not specific spells) – but critical failure wrecks the item! If the item is legendary, a Hidden Lore (Magic Items) roll will identify its common name and known functions.
Magical Writings: The reader of a book must know its language to have any hope of knowing what it’s about. Skimming a spellbook reveals what spells are in it. Roll Hidden Lore (Magical Writings) to discover other properties (“Those who read this will turn into a duck!”), with any failure activating bad effects. Either takes four hours – or an hour and a half with a Speed-Reading roll. Magic scrolls show up to Magery; make a Thaumatology roll to learn what spell a scroll casts.
Potions: These are visible to Magery. Roll Alchemy to analyze a potion’s effects. The tester can use a backpack alchemy lab, take four hours, and at worst ruin the potion on a critical failure . . . or taste the stuff, which takes 10 seconds but means that bad effects affect him on any failure!
item.guid: 10_System_Rules/11_Core_Gurps/General Abilities Article/Dungeon Fantasy/Vol 2. Dungeons/Dungeon Crawling/Loot/Identifying the Good Stuff.md

item.title: Dungeon Parkour
item.description:
Climbing: Most dungeon-sized climbs require one Climbing roll, at no modifier for a steep slope, -2 for a rope straight up, or -3 for a vertical wall (no penalty with climbing spikes). Failure means a fall from halfway up; critical failure means a fall from the top.
Diving: An Acrobatics roll at -4 lets you dive through a narrow opening – under a pendulum, between two rollers, etc. Failure means you end up stuck halfway through, which may hurt! Critical failure adds 1d-3 HP of injury (DR doesn’t protect).
Jumping: If an obstacle is small enough for anyone to hurdle, the GM should let people do so on a DX roll. If it’s wide, it calls for an expert with the Jumping skill, who can run and jump up to skill/2 yards. In either case, success gets you across in one piece. Failure allows a DX roll to catch the far side (no consolation with a shallow hazard) and try a pull-up. Critical failure – or failure on the last-ditch DX roll – means you fall right in.
Leg Up: A friend can boost you to reach a high area. He makes a ST roll while you roll Acrobatics at -2. If you both succeed, you can reach anything up to the sum of your heights and try a pull-up to get yourself up there. Failure by either of you lets you retry, but your partner must pay 1 FP per repeated attempt. On any critical failure, you collapse in a pile and each take 1d-3 HP of injury (DR doesn’t protect).
Pull-Up: Make a ST-based Climbing roll to pull yourself up onto anything you can reach: your height plus 1.5’. On a failure, you hang there and may retry, paying 1 FP per repeated attempt. Critical failure means a strained arm (crippled for 30 minutes) and a fall – bad, if you’re trying to recover from another failed stunt.
Running Climb: If two obstacles are within a couple of yards, you can run at one and kick off back and forth between them to gain additional height before a pull-up. Use the better of Acrobatics or Jumping, at -4 to gain Basic Move/4 yards or -6 to gain Basic Move/2 yards (round up). Failure means a fall from that height; critical failure means maximum falling damage!
Skidding: To cross ice or similar, make a DX or DX-based Skiing roll at the combat penalty for bad footing – usually -2. Failure means you fall; roll DX-4 to stand up before you can try again (this is when the ice weasels attack). Critical failure adds 1d-3 HP of injury (DR doesn’t protect) to a random limb.
Squeezing: Roll against Escape to wiggle through a narrow crack. Success gets you to the other side. Failure means you won’t fit, and can’t retry. Critical failure means you’re stuck and must be rescued.
Swinging: If you can affix a line to an overhead anchor (toss a grapnel, climb up and tie it, etc.), you can swing across a hazard. Regardless of the rope’s true length, effective length can’t exceed the distance from anchor to ground. You can swing up to 3/4 of that length from a vertical rope, or 1.5 times that length if it starts 45° off-vertical. Make an Acrobatics roll at the range penalty for that distance (p. B550). Failure allows you to retry. Critical failure drops you into the hazard!
item.guid: 10_System_Rules/11_Core_Gurps/General Abilities Article/Dungeon Fantasy/Vol 2. Dungeons/Dungeon Crawling/Breaking and Entering/Dungeon Parkour.md

item.title: Suffocation
item.description: If you completely lack air – see Actions After a Grapple, Choke Hold, and Holding Your Breath for examples – you lose 1 FP per second. If you are drowning after a failed Swimming roll, you can get some air, but you also inhale water: roll vs. Swimming every five seconds; failure costs 1 FP (see Swimming,). At 0 FP, you must make a Will roll every second or fall unconscious. You are likely to die unless rescued (see Lost Fatigue Points,). Regardless of FP or HP, you die after four minutes without air. If you get clean air before you die, you stop losing FP and start to recover FP at the usual rate (see Recovering from Fatigue,). If you are unconscious, you awaken once you have 1 FP. If you were drowning, a rescuer must also make a First Aid roll to get the water out of your lungs in order to save you – see Resuscitation. If you went without air for more than two minutes, roll vs. HT to avoid permanent brain damage: -1 to IQ.
item.guid: 10_System_Rules/11_Core_Gurps/General Abilities Article/Basic Set - Campaigns/Chapter 14 - Injuries, Illness and Fatigue/Hazards/Suffocation.md

item.title: FAC - Chicago Factions
item.description:
Type: Federal Government Task Force. Goal: Containment, secrecy, resource monopoly. Attitude: Hunters are "dangerous assets" to be used and discarded. Key NPC: Agent Kessler (Investigating PC - Tessa Thorpe). Type: Corporate Guild. Goal: Profit, media dominance, high-rank gate rights. Requirements: Minimum C-Rank, exclusivity contract. Vibe: "Amazon meets Mercenary Army." Type: Organized Crime / Smugglers. Goal: Wealth, artifact hoarding, evading taxes.
Base: LOC - The Subterranean Market.
Conflict: Currently hunting PC - Ryan Lockwood. Type: Occult Terrorists. Goal: Release the "Essence" of their god from a vessel.
Conflict: Believes PC - Tessa Thorpe is that vessel.

item.title: Chicago_Overview
item.description:
Chicago is a contained crisis city. Life continues on the surface—jobs, traffic, summer festivals—but beneath that normalcy sits a growing lattice of Gates, quarantines, and quiet emergency powers. The city has not collapsed; it has adapted. It is one of the highest Gate-density cities in North America. Official Stance: Recent incidents are "infrastructure failures" or "terrorist activity." Restricted Zones: Labeled as "structurally unstable" or "environmental hazards." Hunter Presence: Framed as "Specialized Contractors" or PMC support for disaster relief. Mana Density: Residual mana is accumulating in underground spaces, warping local geography. Containment: Monsters have escaped containment at least twice. The Economy: A hidden economy runs on Mana Cores, operating beneath the official US Dollar system. LOC - The Loop Guild HQ: The corporate heart of the Hunter industry.
LOC - Navy Pier Gate: A sealed A-Rank Gate, currently a tourist exclusion zone.
LOC - O'Hare Containment Zone: Former airport, now a military mana-processing hub.
LOC - Englewood Dead Zone: Site of a catastrophic Gate Break; totally walled off.
LOC - Calumet Ruins: Industrial wasteland south; frequent illegal Gate activity.
LOC - The Subterranean Market: The "Night Below." The main black market hub.
LOC - The Old Red Line Spur: Staging ground for freelance hunters.
LOC - The Tattoo Tunnels: Where Adepts get illegal rune tattoos.
LOC - The Deep Chambers: High-mana zones for artifact brokering.
FAC - DPS (Dept of Paranormal Security): The federal agency managing the crisis. They prioritize containment over survival.
FAC - The Vanguard: Government-funded special response unit (Military/Hunter hybrid).
FAC - Silver Spear Guild: Corporate, professional, corrupt. They own The Loop.
FAC - Free Hunters Union: Loose coalition of freelancers and mercenaries.
FAC - Black Gate Collective: Cultists who worship Gates as divine.
FAC - Dragovich Syndicate: Smugglers controlling the Subterranean Market. "A Gate opened under the lake. They sealed it, but something escaped into the water."
"Someone in the LOC - Subterranean Market is paying double for Fire-aligned cores." "The Fire Opal Gate has appeared beneath an abandoned monastery on the North Side." "The Vanguard is recruiting mages specifically for a 'suicide run' next week."

item.title: LOC - Surface Chicago POIs
item.description:
Function: Administrative center. Ranking board, contract distribution. Vibe: Corporate sterility. High security. Hunters in suits. Faction: FAC - Silver Spear Guild. Function: Mana processing and military staging. Status: RESTRICTED. Trespassers are shot. Rumor: The government is building a "Mana Bomb" here using S-Rank cores. Function: Containment of a dormant A-Rank Gate. Visual: Surrounded by a translucent magical barrier and physical barricades. Threat: If this Gate breaks, downtown Chicago is gone. Function: Illegal hunting ground.
Status: Lawless. Used by the FAC - Free Hunters Union for unsanctioned raids. Danger: High. Monsters leak here frequently.

item.title: LOC - The Subterranean Market
item.description:
Also known as: "The Below," "Night Below," "Opal Street"Hidden beneath Union Station in abandoned subway spurs and freight tunnels. It operates like a Korean Night Market—loud, crowded, steamy, and chaotic. It is the only place in Chicago where Hunters, criminals, and corporate spies mingle freely.The Golden Rule: No fighting. Violence is punished by immediate execution by the Market Guard. Visuals: Plastic tarps, neon signs powered by mana batteries, steam from food stalls, glowing runes. Smells: Gun oil, ozone, spicy street food, antiseptic ink. Currency: US Dollars and Mana Cores (preferred for high-end gear). Food Stalls: Mana Broth: Restores 1 FP ($50/bowl). Cold Barley Tea: Suppresses Fear penalties for 1 hour. The Demolitions Guy: Lena's contact. Never has a sign. Always "just packing up." Information Brokers: Sit at folding tables with notebooks. Sell rumors for favors. Services: Illegal rune tattoos for Adept Hunters. The Artist: A mute ink-master who claims to remember the "Old World." Risk: Tattoos hurt. HT rolls required to avoid temporary shock. Dragovich's Office: Where NPC - Viktor Dragovich holds court. Artifact Exchange: High-value trading. No cops allowed.
NPC - Viktor Dragovich (The Grey Wolf)
PC - Ryan Lockwood (frequents the gear stalls)

item.title: NPC - Master List
item.description:
📇 NPC Master List Role: Crime Lord / Smuggler Kingpin / Elite Hunter Associated PC: Ryan Lockwood
Location: Subterranean Market, Chicago Underworld Rank: A-Rank Threat (Social/Resource), B-Rank Combatant (~350 Points) Key Details: Controls the smuggling of mana cores and illegal Gate artifacts in Chicago [1]. Motivation: Believes Ryan stole a specific Gate artifact handgun during a black-market auction, or is the person who did (Mistaken Identity) [1]. Tactics: Uses lieutenants and bribed DPS officials; wants Ryan alive for interrogation [1]. Loadout: Exotic magical firearms smuggled from Gates [2]. Role: Ancient Symbiote / Internal Antagonist
Associated PC: Lena Kozlov Location: Inside Lena’s mind/soul (Possession) Rank: S-Rank Knowledge / Variable Power Key Details: Nature: Not an external enemy, but a "Possession Enemy." She is an ancient sorceress queen trying to "complete" Lena [3]. Trigger: Manifests when Lena is unconscious, stressed, or fails Fright Checks, causing chaos [3]. Personality: Arrogant, regal. Views modern hunters as unworthy. Goal: To overwrite Lena eventually, but currently acts as a twisted mentor/guardian [4]. Role: Occult Terrorist Organization
Associated PC: Tessa Thorpe Location: Global / Gate-Adjacent Rank: Faction Threat Key Details: Belief: They believe Tessa is the reincarnated vessel of their god, Koga Thun [5]. The Twist: They believe Tessa is corrupted by her modern humanity and lack of "necrotic" discipline. She must be killed/sacrificed to "free" the divine essence [6]. Assets: "Purifiers" (assassins), Familiar Spirits, Gate-born monstrosities [7]. Connection: Tessa carries a ring belonging to the cult [8]. Role: Final Guardian / Dungeon Anchor
Source: Dungeon of the Fire Opal Rank: High C / Borderline B
Gate Overlay: Gate Boss (C-Rank Limited) Key Stats & Traits: Origin: Undead Human (Opal-bound). A former guardian or noble who died protecting the Opal [9]. DR: 12–15 (Gate Aura). Abilities: Terror aura, Insubstantiality (Ghostly), Possession attempts [10]. Kill Condition: Must destroy or overload the Fire Opal anchor to defeat permanently [11]. Role: Elite Undead / Sub-Boss
Source: Dungeon of the Fire Opal (Original Module) Rank: C+ Traits: Applied Ghostly prefix to a Draugr stat block [10]. Possesses paralysis claws and a banshee-like scream [12]. Role: Opportunist / Interloper
Source: Dungeon of the Fire Opal (Room 12/Laboratory) Rank: C Key Details: Status: Living humanoid, not undead [13]. Motivation: Knows the Fire Opal exists and wants to steal/bargain for it. She is not loyal to the dungeon [14]. Tactics: Uses seals and wards to survive among the undead. Likely willing to trade intel with the PCs for safety or a cut of the loot [14]. Role: Merchants / Quest Givers
Location: Subterranean Market Notable Types: The Tattoo Artist: operates in "The Tattoo Tunnels." Provides emergency rune magic and painful one-shot buffs [15]. The Demolitions Guy: "Just packing up." Unofficial source for Lena’s explosives. Charges high prices [15]. Food Stall Vendors: Serve "Mana Broth" (restores 1 FP) and "Cold Barley Tea" (suppresses fear) [16]. Role: DPS / Suppression Point Total: ~150–200 Key Stats: ST: 11 | DX: 13 | IQ: 10 | HT: 11 Skill: Guns (Pistol/SMG)-14+, Fast-Draw-13. Gear: 9mm SMG or Heavy Pistol. Kevlar Vest (DR 8). Basic comms and dungeon survival kit. Tactics: Suppressive fire to strip Ablative DR from monsters so Mages can finish them [17]. Role: Recon / Traps Point Total: ~150–200 Key Stats: ST: 10 | DX: 14 | IQ: 11 | HT: 11 Skill: Stealth-14, Observation-13, Traps-12, Carbine-12. Gear: Suppressed Carbine or Crossbow. Light armor (mobility focus). Scanner/Sensor gear. Tactics: Identifies ambushes and high-threat targets (Mages/Leaders) for the team [17]. item.title: Aboleth
item.description:
AbolethsInfobox Their original art doesn't really make them look very intimidating.Since the earliest days of my pen-and-paper RPG gaming the aboleths were my favorite monsters. What monster can compete with a primordial fish monster with psionic powers? In D&D 3.5 they were first introduced on the first pages of Monster Manual and then brought to their proper psionic shape in Expanded Psionics Handbook. Finally, the lore was greatly expanded in Lords of Madness, one of my favorite D&D splatbooks. Lords of Madness also introduced three new aboleth variants - the stygian aboleth, the amphibious aboleth, and the uobilyth, also known as the aerial aboleth. I am aware of the other variations from the previous editions, such as the greater aboleth and the grand aboleth, but they won't be present in this post. The entries use psionic abilities from GURPS Psionic Powers and some unique psionic or biologial aboleth abilities. The entries are presented as a racial template and as a typical statblock. Bite (11): thrust 2d-2 cutting (KYOS: 3d-3 cutting). Reach C.Tentacle (11): thrust 4d-2 crushing (KYOS: 5d+1 crushing) + follow-up 1d corrosion (10 1-minute cycles, HT-3 resist). Reach C. 1-3. Being moistened with cool, fresh water negates cycle damage. Using the follow-up damage costs 1 FP.Mucus Cloud (HT): Any creature that makes skin-to-skin contact with the aboleth must make a successful HT roll or lose the ability to breathe air and gain that ability to breathe water for a number of minutes equal to the margin of failure. Using this ability costs 1 FP.Mental Blow (15): The aboleth can overload someone’s brain with a powerful psychic attack. If it wins a Quick Contest of skill vs. his victim’s Will (use the range penalties on the Size and Speed/Range Table (B550)), his victim is stunned. On subsequent turns, he can roll against Will to snap out of it.                Traits: Amphibious; Callous; Doesn’t Breathe (Gills); Double-Jointed; Extra Arms (Extra-Flexible); Extra-Flexible Arms; Extra Attack 1; Infravision; Injury Tolerance (No Neck); Nictitating Membrane 1; No Legs (Semi-Aquatic); Pressure Support 3; Racial Memory (Passive); Reduced Consumption 4; Sharp Teeth; Slippery 3; Speak Underwater; Temperature Tolerance 6 (3xHT to cold, 3xHT to hot); Unaging; Weak Bite.

item.title: RULE - Campaign Constitution
item.description: This document defines the non-negotiable mechanical foundations of the campaign. If a rule is not stated here, it is either: An optional expansion A GM ruling A derived consequence of these rules When in doubt, this document overrides all others.The campaign uses GURPS 4th Edition as its mechanical base.The following books are considered rules-valid sources: GURPS Basic Set (Characters & Campaigns) GURPS Magic GURPS Thaumatology GURPS High-Tech GURPS Dungeon Fantasy (select material) GURPS Monster Hunters (select material) Rules from these books apply only where not superseded by this manifest. Characters are cinematic but mortal Combat is fast, decisive, and dangerous Magic is powerful, flexible, and risky The game assumes competent protagonists, not average civilians Optional cinematic rules may be used at the GM’s discretion, but core mechanics remain grounded in GURPS resolution. Characters may Move and Attack in the same turn without penalty, unless performing: All-Out Attacks All-Out Defenses This rule applies equally to PCs and NPCs Retreats, defenses, and active reactions function normally This replaces standard GURPS movement/attack limitations.All rolls use standard 3d6 roll-under mechanics. Margin of Success (MoS) is always calculated Margin of Failure (MoF) matters when relevant When multiple skills are rolled for a single action, the lowest MoS is used Critical successes and failures follow Basic Set rules unless explicitly overridden.Magic does not use fixed spell lists.All magic is constructed using Symbols, divided into:Create, Move, Control, Sense, Heal, Protect, WeakenAir, Water, Fire, Earth, Body, Mind, Light, Sound, Plant, Animal, Necromancy, Knowledge, Meta-MagicA spell consists of: 1 Verb 1–3 Nouns Example: Create + Fire → Fireball Control + Light → Invisibility To cast a spell: Roll each involved Symbol skill Determine MoS for each roll The lowest MoS becomes the spell’s final MoS MoS determines the spell’s strength and scaling If any required roll fails, the spell fails.MoS determines the tier of effect, not just success.Exact mechanical outcomes are defined by the GM using these tiers as guidance. Magery governs: Maximum complexity of spells Maximum MoS spent per effect category A character may not spend more MoS on a single effect category than their Magery level Excess MoS may still be used, but increases magical risk (see Threshold Magic) Magic uses Threshold Magic, not fatigue-based costs. Each spell adds Threshold (T) instead of FP cost Threshold recovers over time at a fixed rate Exceeding Threshold risks Calamities Minor spells: 1–3 T Moderate spells: 4–6 T Major / Ultimate spells: 7–10+ T Calamities are magical, narrative, and potentially severe. Maintaining a spell is passive Casting a new spell while maintaining one imposes a –2 penalty per maintained spell Failure affects only the newly cast spell unless Threshold backlash occurs Damage uses standard GURPS damage types and DR Area effects, homing effects, control effects, etc. are determined by MoS allocation Magic may create effects that mimic Advantages, Attacks, or Conditions, but does not grant permanent traits unless explicitly allowed Technology Level is modern (TL8 baseline unless stated otherwise) Equipment legality, black markets, and scarcity are enforced Modern weapons are lethal; armor matters Technomagical items exist but are rare and controlled Monsters are ecological entities, not XP bundles Stat blocks emphasize: Behavior Ecology Tactics Monsters may retreat, negotiate, or act irrationally Not all encounters are balanced or fair Character advancement is point-based Advancement may occur through: Training Study Story milestones Exceptional play Power growth is intentional but controlled The GM: Interprets MoS outcomes Defines narrative consequences Adjudicates edge cases However, the GM does not override core mechanics without explicitly declaring a house rule.This document does three crucial things: It locks physics before lore It separates rules from rulings It gives players confidence that mastery is possible Next logical steps (when you’re ready): A Magic Allocation Cheat Sheet (MoS → Damage / Area / Control) A Combat Reference Card for modern + magic interaction A “GM Only” Design Appendix explaining why these rules exist (kept out of player view) When you want, we can tighten this further for table print, or build the next layer without contaminating the core.should each section be its own note? like should 1. System Baseline have its own note?Short answer first, because clarity beats ceremony:No — not at first. The Core Rules Manifest should remain one single note.Now the longer, more interesting answer: why that’s true, and when it stops being true.A constitution is powerful precisely because it’s hard to fragment.Your Core Rules Manifest is not a reference manual. It’s a statement of reality. The moment you split it into multiple notes, three bad things start happening: Authority diffuses Players (and future-you) start asking “Which note overrides which?” Drift sneaks in One section gets quietly updated, another doesn’t. Congratulations — you’ve invented accidental edition wars. Obsidian starts lying Links make everything look equally important, even when it isn’t. A constitution lives or dies by coherence. One file forces coherence.Right now, your manifest should be: One document that can be printed, handed to a player, and sworn upon. If you cannot print it as a single artifact without losing meaning, it’s too fragmented.There is a correct time to split — just not yet.You split only when a section gains subordinate structure.Here’s the rule of thumb: A section becomes its own note only when it needs children. Let’s apply that to your examples.1. System Baseline This is declarative. It names books and authority. It has no moving parts.If it were its own note, you’d gain nothing and risk someone “editing the foundation.”Same for: Tone and Power Assumptions Action Economy GM Authority Clause These are axioms, not systems.Unified Symbol Magic SystemRight now, it belongs in the manifest as a law. Later, it will absolutely spawn: Magic Allocation Tables Example Spells Edge Cases Design Rationale Player vs GM guidance When that happens, the manifest keeps the summary, and a separate document becomes: “Unified Symbol Magic — Full Rules” The manifest links outward, but never imports detail inward.These will eventually want their own notes: Monsters (already happening naturally) Equipment economies Advancement rules Faction mechanics Dungeon / Gate rules But note the pattern: Those are procedural systems, not constitutional laws.Here’s the rule that prevents vault collapse: Top-level documents never link sideways. They only link downward. Your Core Rules Manifest should: Sit at the root Have no backlinks that alter it Be referenced, not edited casually Everything else orbits it.For now, I’d suggest:00 - CORE RULES MANIFEST.md 01 - Magic System (Expansion).md 02 - Combat & Damage Clarifications.md 03 - Monsters & Ecology.md 04 - Equipment & Economy.md GM - Design Notes (Private).mdNotice: The manifest stays singular Expansions explain, but do not redefine GM notes are quarantined Fragmentation feels productive. Coherence is productive.You’ve already done the hard work: designing a system that hangs together. The manifest’s job is to freeze that coherence.Once the ice is solid, then you can build cities on top of it.Next time, if you want, we can: Mark which sentences in the manifest are link anchors Decide which sections are immutable vs versioned Or design a “Player Cut” vs “GM Cut” without duplicating rules You’re building this the right way.

item.title: Verb - Weaken
item.description:
Function: Damage, debuff, decay, corrode, erode, exhaust, or impair. Weaken replaces Destroy in this system. Deal direct damage (burn/crush/toxic/fatigue) depending on Noun Apply debuffs (DX penalties, slow, impaired senses) via Noun + GM ruling Corrode materials (Weaken + Earth), rot (Weaken + Plant/Body), drain life (Weaken + Necromancy) Disrupt magic (Weaken + Meta-Magic) if your campaign allows it Surgical precision patterns (add Control) Persistent hazards from nothing (add Create for zones/fields) Weaken + Fire: burning damage, scorching aura, ignition, “hellfire” with Necromancy Weaken + Earth: shatter, crack armor, collapse structures, rust/corrode Weaken + Sound: concussive damage, stun, disorientation Weaken + Mind: fear, confusion, cognitive debuffs (usually resisted) Weaken + Necromancy: life drain, soul harm, decay, anti-undead smite Primary “damage Verb” For massive AOEs, damage-per-target usually drops as MoS is spent on scale Margin of Success (MoS)
Threshold Magic
Building a Spell

item.title: Verb - Sense
item.description:
Function: Detect, reveal, analyze, perceive, or extend awareness. Detect creatures, hazards, magic signatures Reveal hidden things (secret doors, illusions) with the right Noun Analyze targets (weak points, resistances) with Knowledge Expanded perception (hear through walls with Sound, heat-sense with Fire) Tactical read (Sense + Mind) for intent/emotion (GM-defined) Direct harm or alteration (add Weaken/Control) Perfect omniscience (range, cover, wards still matter) Sense + Knowledge: appraisal, weakness scan, bestiary read Sense + Light: true-seeing, reveal invisibility, detect illusions Sense + Mind: surface thoughts, emotion reading, lie detection (limits vary) Sense + Necromancy: detect undead/spirits, possession, death-taint Sense + Sound: echolocation, locate footsteps, detect silence fields Often 1 second; commonly a “setup” action MoS often buys detail/clarity rather than raw power Margin of Success (MoS)
Threshold Magic
Building a Spell

item.title: Verb - Protect
item.description:
Function: Defend, shield, reinforce, ward, buffer, and resist. Add DR to a target (reinforced flesh, force armor) Provide resistances via appropriate Nouns (fire/cold/mind/necromancy) Create barriers (sometimes treated as Protect alone; some tables require Create too) Prevent conditions (anti-stun, fear ward) with Mind/Light/Meta-Magic Permanent enchantment (handle as separate long-term magic) True immunity without very high MoS and serious cost Protect + Body: toughness, “stone-skin” DR, stabilization Protect + Mind: mental shield, anti-charm, emotion buffering Protect + Light: radiant shield, concealment defense, glare barrier Protect + Meta-Magic: spell shield, dampening field, anti-magic shell Protect + Earth/Water/Air: elemental screens (stone wall, water curtain, wind barrier) Often the fastest defensive option MoS typically buys DR, duration, and number of allies protected Margin of Success (MoS)
Threshold Magic
Building a Spell

item.title: Verb - Move
item.description:
Function: Push, pull, accelerate, reposition, or transport something. Telekinesis-style motion (throw a rock, yank a weapon) Propel projectiles (pebbles → bullets with Earth) Mobility bursts (dash/step) with Body or Air Knockback waves (Move + Air / Sound) Redirect/deflect objects in flight (often add Control for precision) Fine “puppeteering” (add Control) Creating matter/energy from nothing (add Create) Full teleportation without campaign permission (treat as high-tier/high-cost) Move + Air: gusts, air cuts, shockwaves, flight bursts Move + Earth: throw debris, launch stone spears, disarm by yanking weapons Move + Sound: concussive wave, vibration shove Move + Body: speed burst, leap enhancement Move + Water: water whip, pressure jets, drag/swirl Excellent battlefield control and repositioning Many Move effects allow active defense unless AOE If it’s fast, violent, or repositioning, Move is usually involved If it’s precise, add Control Margin of Success (MoS)

item.title: Verb - Heal
item.description:
Function: Restore, repair, cleanse, and stabilize. Restore HP (and optionally FP if your campaign allows) Stop bleeding, stabilize mortal wounds Cure poisons/disease (usually requires Body + sufficient MoS) Cleanse corruption/taint (often Light or Meta-Magic) Repair living tissue; “living-like” constructs only if permitted Raise the dead (usually Create/Control + Necromancy; high tier/high cost) Heal objects reliably (use other rules if desired) Heal + Body: HP recovery, cure poison/disease, fatigue restoration (if allowed) Heal + Mind: calm panic, treat trauma, remove fear effects Heal + Light: purification, cleanse curses/taint (GM-defined) Heal + Necromancy: exorcism, spirit restoration, undead “repair” (setting-dependent) In-combat healing is limited by time/risk/cost MoS usually buys extra HP, removes conditions, or extends coverage Margin of Success (MoS)

item.title: Verb - Create
item.description:
Function: Bring matter, energy, or an effect into existence. Conjure elemental attacks (firebolt, ice spike, stone spear) Create barriers (hard-light wall, stone rampart) Generate temporary constructs/tools (light platforms, stone steps) Produce persistent zones (wall of fire, fog bank) if MoS is spent on area/duration Summon simple entities with the right Noun (e.g., Necromancy for undead) as allowed by the GM Precisely shape/steer complex effects (add Control) Launch created effects at convincing speed (add Move if needed) Permanently create valuable matter (GM should cap this via cost/ritual/special rules) Create + Fire: fireball, flame jet, ignition, burning aura Create + Water: jets, ice formation (often add Earth for shaping spikes) Create + Light: illusions, flashes, hard-light constructs Create + Earth: walls, spikes, weapons, debris fields Create + Necromancy: raise undead, summon spirits (GM sets limits) Usually 1–2 seconds for simple attacks; 3 seconds for “ultimate” area denial For AOEs: MoS often goes to area + duration more than damage If the player wants a “named spell,” ask: What Verb? What Noun(s)? Spells scale via MoS spending (damage vs. area vs. duration vs. control) If it sounds like finesse, require Control Margin of Success (MoS)

item.title: Verb - Control
item.description:
Function: Shape, guide, command, modulate, or maintain an existing phenomenon. Shape elements (fire ribbon, water tentacle, stone hands) “Smart” targeting (avoid allies, home in, selective effects) Sustained manipulation (hold a vortex, keep a shield stable) Command entities in-domain (animals/plants/undead) if allowed Modulate intensity (dim light, damp sound, throttle flames) Create from nothing (add Create) Move huge masses at speed (add Move as needed) Override free will trivially (Mind control is resisted and MoS-hungry) Control + Light: invisibility, illusions, mirror images, shadow shaping Control + Mind: calm, fear, charm, domination (resisted) Control + Fire/Air/Water/Earth: shaped attacks, cages, walls, whips Control + Meta-Magic: tune/suppress/alter other spells, stabilize effects Control is the “precision tax” Best verb for ally-safe AOEs and complex battlefield effects If the player says “I want it to curve / avoid allies / lock onto targets,” require Control Use Control spending tiers to price complexity Margin of Success (MoS)

item.title: Black Pudding
item.description: Black Pudding [Monster Manual, page 201]Engulf: If the black pudding starts its turn in close combat with prey or can move there on its turn, it tries to engulf its target; no attack roll is necessary and its quarry may defend only by dodging and retreating. In addition, if it is moving through an SM+2 or smaller creature, this counts as an automatic slam attempt (Pyramid # 3-77, p. 6). Failure to dodge means being sucked inside and pinned if of lower SM than the black pudding, or partly stuck in the black pudding and grappled if of equal or greater SM. The victim can break free by winning a Quick Contest of ST (allowed only every 10 seconds if pinned; and on a 17 or 18, he becomes so entangled that he cannot escape on his own); the black pudding has +10 to ST if pinning or +5 if grappling. Engulfed victims cannot breathe. If they run out of breath before they break free, they start to suffocate (see Holding Your Breath, p. B351 and Suffocation, p. B436). The typical black pudding can pin/grapple one foe; later enemies are pushed along in front of it unless they win a Quick Contest of ST to prevent it from moving. The black pudding can actively constrict engulfed victims, attacking them each turn with a Constriction Attack (p. B43). This ability has effective ST 24.Acid: The creature secretes a digestive acid that dissolves organic material and metal, but does not affect stone. Any organic or metal creature or object touching the black pudding takes 1d-1 corrosion damage per second. Engulfed creatures and objects take it as Large-Area Injury (p. B400).Ooze Senses: An ooze’s entire body is a primitive sensory organ that can ascertain prey by scent and vibration. It uses standard range penalties instead of a -1/yard penalty when detecting smells, and gets a +5 bonus on Smell and Taste rolls (Sense roll 15). Its smell operates both in air and underwater. In addition, the ooze can detect vibrations in the air. It can locate prey in the dark, but cannot detect details. To use Vibration Sense, the ooze must make a Sense roll (10). Consult the Size and Speed/Range Table (p. B550) and apply separate bonuses for the target’s size and speed, and a penalty for the range to the target. Wind will generate “noise” that interferes with this sense. Find the speed of the wind on the table and assess the relevant speed penalty. A successful roll reveals the rough size, location, speed, and direction of movement of the target, allowing the ooze to move to it and attempt to engulf it.                Traits: Amphibious; Blindness; item.title: LOC - O'Hare Containment Zone
item.description: A dual-use federal annex embedded inside O’Hare.Official designation: “Joint Aviation Security Modernization Annex” What the public sees: One runway “under long-term resurfacing” A cargo terminal marked “federal operations” Increased TSA + National Guard presence Drone restrictions expanded Occasional military aircraft parked far from passenger gates Most travelers never get near the restricted side. Terminals 1–3 active Domestic and international flights continue Retail and passenger operations normal Visible but non-threatening security presence Air travel remains a symbol that “the world is still functioning.”This is the gray space. Cargo Terminal 5 partially federalized One maintenance hangar cluster converted A decommissioned runway sector used for testing Controlled access roads branching off main airport arteries To most airport workers: “It’s a federal training area.” Hidden behind secure fencing and blast walls: Core stabilization chambers Containment vaults Density measurement labs Artifact quarantine rooms This is where monster cores get: graded catalogued stabilized shipped Military cargo aircraft staged Hunter contractor staging rooms Gear lockers Briefing rooms Tactical airlift capability If a Gate opens in the Midwest, response time is measured in hours.On the “under repair” runway: Portable mana dampening arrays Field tests of sealing tech Live-fire containment drills Artifact stress testing This runway is long enough to: chase large entities deploy heavy weapons test aerial anomalies Airports are honeycombs underneath.Below MALC: Mana compression research Energy extraction experiments Core amplification testing Secure holding cells There are rumors of: Something airborne that cannot leave its chamber A Gate fragment under study A “partial seal” being reverse engineered Outer ring: Normal airport policing Increased federal presence Surveillance disguised as aviation security Inner ring: Military police Arcane suppression grids Hardened blast doors Black badge access only If civilians wander too close? They’re rerouted politely.If hunters wander too close? They’re questioned seriously.Would the government do this?Yes.Because: Airports already handle sensitive federal traffic. They have perimeter control. They have hardened infrastructure. They have massive cargo capacity. They are strategically connected. Shutting O’Hare down screams crisis.Embedding a black-site inside it screams competence.Keeping O’Hare active gives you: Hunters boarding commercial flights while classified cargo loads nearby. A containment test happening during peak air traffic. A monster escaping into baggage handling. A mana surge disrupting navigation systems. A corporate spy disguised as an airline contractor. A Gate flare interfering with radar. You get thriller energy, not bunker energy.

item.title: LOC - Navy Pier Gate
item.description: Threat Rating: A-Rank Condition: Sealed but unstable Public Story: “Structural damage and ongoing renovations” Real Status: Active mana pressure behind containment barriers Control: Joint Federal + City + Classified Task Group The Gate opened: Inside the Festival Hall complex During off-peak hours Initial manifestation: gravity distortion + light inversion Witness footage was scrubbed within hours.The response was immediate — but wrong.Federal containment assumed: Urban dungeon interior Limited surface breach risk Predictable monster behavior They were incorrect.This Gate isn’t just high-damage.It’s high-reality.Confirmed internal characteristics: Non-Euclidean interior geometry Floating architectural fragments Spatial folding corridors Creatures not bound by gravity Time dilation pockets Two recon teams entered.One team returned altered. The other never exited.The Gate was sealed externally before a full clear.The “seal” is not mystical.It’s: Physical barricades Electromagnetic interference grids Mana-dampening arrays (experimental) Armed federal response at all hours Structural reinforcement of the pier deck The Ferris wheel is dark at night now.No fireworks this summer.Public-facing measures: Construction fencing Renovation permits Closed attractions Increased Coast Guard patrols Drone surveillance Most Chicagoans think it’s: “Storm damage repairs.” The wealthy are quietly leaving downtown.Navy Pier is symbolic.If this becomes public: National media explosion Financial panic Federal emergency declarations International signaling of instability This is not a neighborhood problem.This is optics warfare.If cleared: A-Rank core yield Unique artifacts Spatial manipulation materials Possible gravity-aligned magic resources Corporations are salivating.The Guild is cautious.The government is divided. Ferris wheel lights flicker when inactive Boats report compass deviation offshore Birds avoid the pier Glass vibrates without wind Water near the pier has micro-whirlpools at night The seal is holding.For now.“Destroy it entirely. Collapse the structure if needed.”“Study it. This is a breakthrough in applied spatial science.”“Do not attempt full clear without S-Rank presence.”Some believe: The Gate is not random The lake is “watching” Something beneath Lake Michigan stirred This is not a dungeon crawl.It’s: A stealth infiltration A political minefield A time bomb A prestige contract A forbidden temptation If the PCs enter this Gate: They are no longer small players. They are operating in a national crisis. The main promenade Select restaurants Some retail shops Portions of the outdoor areas Daytime boat tours (restricted routes) Crowds are thinner than usual, but tourists still come.Security presence is visibly higher — but framed as: “summer safety measures” “infrastructure updates” “crowd control improvements” Festival Hall interior (where the Gate opened) Several internal corridors Underground maintenance access Portions of the pier’s central structure Rooftop access These areas are behind: construction walls “Renovation in Progress” signage armed but low-profile security The city understands something crucial: If you shut down a landmark, people assume catastrophe. If you partially shut it down, they assume construction. So the pier operates at maybe 60% capacity.Enough life to look normal. Enough restriction to hide something. Ferris wheel occasionally “under maintenance” Random closures with short notice Helicopters at night Lake patrol activity increased Strange humming in some areas Unusual no-drone enforcement Conspiracy forums are active. Mainstream media is uninterested.The Gate is sealed inside the closed section.The seal: Is mechanical + experimental mana dampening Is monitored constantly Has fluctuated twice in the past month Guild intel classifies it as: “Dormant under pressure. Not resolved.” Which means:It’s not dead.Three reasons: Economic optics Chicago cannot afford to project instability. Federal denial posture Full closure = admission of uncontrolled anomaly. Testing behavior The government wants to observe: mana diffusion under civilian load structural strain under vibration emotional/psychic interference Yes, they are measuring whether large crowds affect the Gate.They are not telling anyone.If PCs visit Navy Pier: No immediate danger Security watches everyone Subtle mana distortion checks Rumor opportunities Increased military presence Magical interference Restricted access Possible containment alarms Much tighter lockdown Coast Guard presence Federal rapid-response team on standby The Navy Pier Gate is not dangerous because it’s open.It’s dangerous because: It’s sealed imperfectly. It’s in the middle of the skyline. And if it fails during peak summer hours… That’s not a dungeon incident.That’s a national trauma event.These are businesses the city needs open to maintain the illusion. Mid-range seafood restaurant (reduced seating) Deep-dish pizza spot (busy but understaffed) Tourist burger & bar chain Coffee shop (heavily frequented by security personnel) Ice cream / funnel cake stand (seasonal, open weekends only) Vibe: Open, but slightly emptier than peak summer. Staff are jumpy when Festival Hall is mentioned. National coffee chain Local craft coffee cart Popcorn / cotton candy vendor Bottled water and souvenir kiosks Vibe: High foot traffic. Tourists unaware. Employees whisper about “construction delays.” Ferris wheel (intermittent operation) Carousel Some arcade games Outdoor seating areas Public art exhibits Not operating: Indoor festival events Large exhibitions Major summer concert programming The Ferris wheel occasionally “shuts down for maintenance.” Players may notice it stalls briefly when mana fluctuations spike. Souvenir stores T-shirt shops Chicago sports merchandise Jewelry stand Kids toy store Foot traffic: moderate, not packed. Limited sightseeing boat tours Dinner cruises (shortened routes) Kayak rentals (restricted zones) Coast Guard presence is higher than normal. Certain lake coordinates are strictly off-limits.These appear open but are effectively dead. Event rental offices Indoor theater spaces Private banquet halls Conference areas Some upper-level offices These areas are “under renovation.” Festival Hall interior Maintenance corridors Loading docks near the Gate anchor point Sub-basement access Several rooftop sections Construction walls are professionally done. Security presence is subtle but constant.If they look closely: Security personnel in plain clothes Federal-style unmarked SUVs Radio chatter using unfamiliar call signs Tourists occasionally escorted away from restricted corridors Slight static in cell service near certain walls Light pressure sensation (mages especially) Behind the scenes, the following quietly operate: Federal monitoring office (temporary) Mana flux instrumentation Structural stress monitoring Rapid response containment team on standby Psychological profiling team reviewing witness footage But none of that is visible unless players go digging.If they attempt: Accessing closed corridors Questioning staff aggressively Casting magic openly Flying drones Scanning for mana They will trigger: Soft surveillance first Then quiet intervention Then firm removal This is not Englewood. This is optics territory.Navy Pier should feel: 80% normal 15% tense 5% wrong That 5% is where your campaign lives.

item.title: LOC - Calumet Ruins
item.description:
Think steel mills, slag heaps, rail yards, river pollution, and forgotten infrastructure. Calumet is where Gates don’t hide — they fester.Use six zones here. Calumet is larger, messier, and more openly hostile than Englewood.(Primary Gate Cluster)Map Marking Dark red fill Gear / flame icons Jagged borders What This Is Former steel mill complexes Blast furnaces and rolling mills The first Calumet Gate opened inside a furnace hall Rules Impact Extreme heat pockets Fire-aligned mana −1 FP every 30 minutes without protection Fire/metal monsters are territorial and aggressive Notes Multiple Gates opened here over time Some sealed, some dormant This is where Fire Opal–type Gates are more likely (Environmental Death Zone)Map Marking Orange-black mottled fill Toxic / collapse icons What This Is Mountains of industrial waste Sinkholes Toxic runoff Cracked ground venting heat and gas Rules Impact HT checks vs toxins Movement penalties Random environmental damage Monsters burrow and ambush Notes Looks inert until it isn’t Government pretends this is an EPA issue (Monster Transit Zone)Map Marking Yellow dashed outline Train / tunnel icons What This Is Abandoned rail lines Switching yards Collapsed maintenance tunnels Rules Impact High encounter frequency Monsters use rails like highways Easy ambushes Loud combat attracts reinforcements Notes Hunters hate this zone Cultists use it to move cores (Aquatic Hazard Zone)Map Marking Purple-blue shading Water / biohazard icons What This Is Polluted river sections Flooded industrial basements Submerged tunnels Rules Impact Waterborne monsters Disease checks Visibility penalties Unstable footing Notes Some Gates open partially underwater Creatures migrate upstream at night (Unofficial Control Zone)Map Marking Green outline Wrench / crate icons What This Is Warehouses and yards used by hunters Temporary camps Core processing sites Rules Impact Easier resupply Faster extraction Increased chance of hunter NPCs Guild influence is visible here Notes This zone exists because Calumet produces valuable cores Conflicts happen, but quietly (Hidden Subsurface Layer)Map Marking Black dashed overlay Utility icons What This Is Power conduits Cooling tunnels Drainage systems Old bomb shelters Rules Impact Navigation penalties Monsters appear where they shouldn’t Gates can “bleed” between zones Notes This is how Calumet connects to Englewood’s subterranean spill The two zones talk to each other Calumet is where the government lets things get ugly, because it’s easier to justify. South-southeast of Englewood Follow the Calumet River Wrap zones around: old steel mills rail corridors industrial dead space Overlay order (top → bottom): C-6 Black Infrastructure C-4 River C-1 Furnace Core C-2 Slag Fields C-3 Rail Graveyard C-5 Hunter Strip It’s where Fire Opal–class threats aren’t rare It produces high-value cores It attracts: cultists corporations reckless hunters It connects underground to Englewood If Englewood is a warning…Calumet is exploitation.I can: Create an actual Calumet zone map image Write encounter tables per zone Tie Calumet directly into the Fire Opal Gate ecology Add corporate faction presence Show how Calumet escalates over time Just tell me whether you want the map image, zone notes, or encounters next.What is the history of Calumet?Here’s a grounded, Chicago-real history of the Calumet area, tuned so it naturally explains why it became a Gate magnet instead of feeling like “because magic.”

4A place that was never meant to be quiet again.Long before furnaces and rail yards, the Calumet region was: marshland slow water liminal ground between lake, river, and land Indigenous peoples avoided permanent settlement here. Not for superstition—because the ground shifted, flooded, swallowed structures.Even then, it was a place that didn’t like being owned.Chicago’s south industrial expansion turned Calumet into a machine.Steel mills, coke ovens, rail yards, and ship canals were packed together because: water access rail access political indifference to pollution What that created: constant vibration extreme heat gradients chemical runoff buried infrastructure layered on buried infrastructure Calumet wasn’t just polluted. It was mechanically stressed for a century.Steel collapsed. Industry fled.What stayed behind: sealed tunnels abandoned furnaces slag heaps undocumented voids contaminated groundwater rusting machines still under tension The land didn’t recover. It hollowed out.By the 1990s, Calumet was already: semi-forgotten politically convenient to ignore dangerous in mundane ways Which made it perfect later.For decades, Calumet existed as: “future redevelopment land” EPA problem zones rail corridors no one wanted to map fully Nothing supernatural—just: sinkholes unexplained fires toxic gas releases structural collapses But here’s the key part for your setting: Calumet already behaved like a place where reality leaked. So when Gates began appearing globally…It didn’t open in a neighborhood.It opened inside: a sealed furnace hall surrounded by slag beneath rusted catwalks above flooded tunnels Sensors didn’t notice immediately. Cameras didn’t work right. Heat signatures blended with the environment.By the time anyone understood what had happened: monsters had space to spread mana had room to pool no civilians were present to trigger alarms The government’s internal conclusion was chilling: “If a Gate had to open somewhere, this was the least bad place.” That decision shaped everything.In-world logic, not GM fiat: The ground is fractured and hollow Old infrastructure forms natural containment chambers Heat and pressure align with fire- and metal-aligned Gates Subterranean networks allow migration Political will to fully cleanse the area is low Calumet isn’t cursed.It’s convenient.Today, Calumet is: semi-abandoned semi-monitored quietly exploited It’s where: dangerous Gates are allowed to fester high-value - monster cores are harvested experimental containment is tested failures are buried Englewood taught the city a lesson.Calumet is where that lesson is applied.Among hunters, Calumet is known as: “The Furnace” “The Open Wound” “Where the city bleeds money” You don’t go there to survive. You go there to get paid.And maybe not come back.This lets you: justify recurring Gates without escalation fatigue explain government tolerance seed corporate and cult interest tie Fire Opal–style threats naturally to the region contrast Englewood’s tragedy with Calumet’s exploitation Englewood was an accident.Calumet is a choice.

item.title: LOC - Englewood Dead Zone
item.description: Englewood wasn’t destroyed by a single catastrophe. It was bled out by a bad decision, made quietly, and covered up efficiently.Englewood was the site of the first large-scale containment failure in Chicago—and the place where the government learned that Gates can’t be handled like riots or disasters.Everything that followed across the city was shaped by what happened here.A Gate opened beneath abandoned rail infrastructure near the old industrial corridors. At first, it looked like another low-tier urban Gate: Small monster incursions Limited mana bleed Containable footprint Federal response classified it as “manageable.”That was wrong.Instead of a full clear, containment teams: sealed surface access deployed sensors delayed entry Why? manpower shortages inter-agency conflict fear of civilian exposure pressure to “not escalate” This allowed mana saturation to build.Englewood had: abandoned basements old utility tunnels undocumented storm drains vacant housing stock Mana didn’t stay put. It spread sideways, seeping into places no map fully captured.Creatures: moved into empty buildings used basements as lairs learned patrol patterns avoided daylight This wasn’t a wave. It was urban entrenchment.For roughly six days, Englewood experienced: unexplained fires power failures “gang violence” spikes missing persons first responder withdrawals Police scanners recorded things they weren’t trained to describe.Then… silence. evacuated several blocks quietly reclassified the zone as structurally unsafe erected “temporary” barriers restricted utility access Then they did something new.They let hunters in.Not officially. Not publicly. But deliberately.Englewood became the first proving ground for freelance containment.The Gate was eventually neutralized, but: not all monsters were killed some escaped underground some adapted to surface conditions mana residue never fully dissipated Official story: “Infrastructure failure combined with criminal activity.” Unofficial truth: Englewood was a lesson written in bodies. Sections are walled off Others are “open” but watched Utilities are unreliable by design Surveillance is heavy but indirect The ground feels wrong in places Hunters know: it’s not clean it’s not safe it’s not finished The government knows: full disclosure here would unravel everything Englewood is: proof Gates can metastasize the reason Chicago’s response is so harsh now a source of feral monsters a cult recruitment ground a place where people saw too much It’s why: Lakeshore is locked down fast the Loop is watched obsessively the Subterranean Market expanded hunters are tolerated instead of crushed “Something’s still alive down there.” “They never found the original anchor.” “A crew went in last month. No exit log.” “Cores from Englewood behave wrong.” “That place remembers violence.” Some of those are true.Englewood isn’t a dungeon. It’s a scar.You don’t clear it. You survive it. And you don’t forget what it taught the city.

item.title: Overview
item.description: Chicago in June 2025 is a contained crisis city. Life continues on the surface—jobs, traffic, summer festivals—but beneath that normalcy sits a growing lattice of Gates, quarantines, and quiet emergency powers. The public knows something is wrong. They do not know how wrong.The city has not collapsed. It has adapted. A series of "containment incidents" tied to infrastructure failures, chemical leaks, and extremist activity. Certain neighborhoods are restricted due to "structural instability" or "environmental hazards." Increased federal presence is framed as counter-terrorism and disaster preparedness. Viral footage of "animals" or "riots" is dismissed as hoaxes or misinterpretations. Most people assume this is temporary. Chicago is one of the highest Gate-density cities in North America. Several Gates have already been neutralized; others remain dormant, sealed, or unacknowledged. Residual mana is accumulating in underground spaces, old infrastructure, and abandoned buildings. Monsters have escaped containment at least twice. Cult activity is confirmed and escalating. Hunters understand that Chicago is being managed, not saved. Emergency authority invoked under existing disaster and homeland security frameworks. A dedicated task force operates quietly through shell agencies and utilities departments. Data is classified aggressively; whistleblowers disappear into legal limbo. City Hall cooperates under pressure. Police and fire departments receive limited briefings. First responders are told to withdraw from certain zones without explanation. Officially, no supernatural threat exists.Chicago hosts a large freelance hunter population, larger than average due to: High Gate frequency Abundant underground access points Strong black-market infrastructure Hunter culture in Chicago is: Pragmatic Suspicious Highly networked Less heroic, more professional Reputation matters. Carelessness spreads quickly.Beneath the streets exists a parallel ecosystem: Abandoned subway spurs Flooded service tunnels Utility corridors Forgotten bomb shelters These spaces house: The Subterranean Market Hunter safehouses Illegal clinics Artifact brokers Cult hideouts This underground is alive, shifting nightly. Government containment units (covert) Independent hunter crews Corporate interests (research & salvage) Religious and esoteric cults Information brokers and fixers No single group is fully in control. Gates appear unpredictably but favor older structures and underground spaces. Some Gates destabilize after partial clearing. Smaller "micro-Gates" open briefly, often ignored until damage is done. Mana residue persists after closure, warping environments. The Fire Opal Gate is one of the most dangerous confirmed examples. Summer heat mixed with unease Increased police presence without explanation Closed streets and construction zones everywhere Rumors spreading faster than facts A sense that something big is coming Chicago feels watched.Use Chicago as: A living hub between Gates A pressure cooker for faction conflict A place where choices have visible consequences A city that reacts to hunter actions Nothing resets between sessions. "A Gate opened under the lake. They sealed it, but something escaped." "Someone is paying double for fire-aligned cores." "A cult thinks a god is about to be reborn." "The tunnels are changing. Old maps don’t work anymore." "Hunters went in last week. No bodies came out." Some of these are true.Chicago is not a dungeon.It is a system under stress.The players are not saviors.They are specialists operating in the cracks.
